lines.text: Dickon knows things no one else knows.
Morning, Miss.
Who are you?
Betty. It's Martha's free day and she's gone to help her mother in the country.
[Mrs. Medlock walks in]
Is your, uh, toothache gone?

[confused]
Toothache?

[smiling knowingly at Mrs. Medlock]
The toothache you didn't have.
I just have the most marvelous idea; after the governers ball why don't we go for a breakfast picnic along the river?
Oh yes, yes, I'd like that very much.
I don't think I should feel like a picnic after dancing all night.
Nonsense.
Besides, I shan't be going to the ball, Stephen has booked me a passage to England. He says there's some kind of plague in the provinces.
Oh, there's always some kind of plague in the provinces, Mrs. Crawford. I wouldn't let that stop me from going to the ball.
[rings servant bell vigorously and ominously no one responds]
Will you stay with me Mary, please?
Well, since you said please. But if you scream once more, I'll smother you with the pillow.
And she would, too.
I'm Master Colin's nurse.
Then I feel sorry for you!
Killed in the war, Dickon. In a forest called the Argonne.
If Dickon had to die, he would have chosen a place with green and growing things.
To die so young...
[sighs]
Who's to know?
Dickon knew.

[after a pause]
Aye, Dickon knew.
Please might I have a bit of earth? To make a garden? I love gardens.

[looking away]
There was someone... someone very dear... who loved gardens, too.

[appears near tears and then abruptly changes tone]
Go now, leave me.

[curtsies in relief and leaves]
Thank you.
[last lines]
When I was at Oxford, I asked you to marry me. When I was in France I wrote to you and asked you to marry me. Why didn't you answer me, Mary?
Because I wanted you to ask me here in our garden.

[smiles]
Of course. I should have known.
[pause]
Will you marry me, Mary Lennox?
Yes.
[they kiss]
Come see our garden.
Where you tend a rose, a thistle canna' grow.
